text: We examined chemokine gene expression following the differentiation of a monocyte , macrophage cell lineage .
The human monoblastic cell line , U937 was differentiated to macrophages by the treatment with either phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) , retinoic acid ( RA ) , or vitamin D3 ( VitD3 ) .

The gene expression of <extra_id_0> interferon (IFN)-inducible protein 10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IP-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ( a CXC chemokine ) was markedly augmented by the <extra_id_0> IFNgamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment in PMA - or RA-differentiated U937 cells , but only marginally in undifferentiated or VitD3 - treated cells .

text: In contrast , another inducible gene expression of <extra_id_0> monocyte chemotactic protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( a CC chemokine ) and the activation of the transcriptional factor ( FcRFgamma ) bound to the gamma response region were similarly or less abundantly induced by <extra_id_0> IFNgamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment in PMA - or RA-differentiated U937 cells , indicating that increased <extra_id_0> IP-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA induction was not due to the augmented ability of the cells to respond to the presence of <extra_id_0> IFNgamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
